segments.key_quote: When the Sun son of the Brahmana Ashwathama saw that his horses were tired he considered that there was no alternative for protection outside of his using the ultimate weapon.
segments.summary: The speaker narrates the story of Ashwathama using the Brahmastra, explaining the context of Arjuna chasing him and Ashwathama's desperation.

segments.key_quote: The most intelligent man is called a Brahmana. And it is not a hereditary title.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that being a Brahmana is not hereditary but based on qualification, and Ashwathama is referred to as the son of a Brahmana because he lacks the necessary qualities.

segments.key_quote: A Brahmana naturally is endowed with some characteristics by which he is called a Brahmana.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the qualities of a Brahmana as described in the Bhagavad Gita, contrasting it with the modern misconception of Brahmanas being determined by birth.
segments.transcript: Brahmana in the strict sense of the term being used for somebody means the person has got the qualifications of a Brahmana. In the Bhagavad Gita, in the Bhagavad Gita this is mentioned: Shamo Dhamo Tapasyaucham Shanti Rajyavam Evacha Gyanam Vigyanam Astikyam Brahma Karma Swabhavajam. A Brahmana naturally is endowed with some characteristics by which he is called a Brahmana. So nine qualities by which Brahmanas work are specifically enumerated in the Bhagavad Gita in the 18th chapter. Hmm. Here Ashwathama because he is not having the qualifications, therefore he cannot be called a Brahmana. Therefore earlier he was referred to as Brahmabandhu, and in this verse he is referred to as Dvijatmaja, the son of a Brahmana. Earlier he was called the friend of a Brahmana. A friend or a son of a Brahmana, well fully qualified can be called a Brahmana and not otherwise. So somebody to be called as a Brahmana should have the qualification, unlike in modern times. Simply somebody is taken birth in a Brahmana family, therefore they are called Brahman, but that is not correct. That is not the proper way in which somebody should be called as a Brahmana.

segments.key_quote: Since Ashwathama's decision is immature, he is purposely called herein the son of a Brahmana.

segments.key_quote: One must act as a Brahmana. One must have the characteristics of a Brahmana. If he does not have those characteristics, there is no harm in referring him as the son of a Brahmana.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of acting and having the characteristics of a Brahmana, and that referring to someone as the son of a Brahmana is acceptable if they lack these qualities, highlighting the need for training, education, and culture.

Dronacharya is qualified, highly qualified. He was expert, expert Brahmana. So Ashwatthama is not similarly having the characteristics like Dronacharya. Therefore Ashwatthama, it is proper to refer him as Dujatmaja. So here Srila Prabhupada explains, anyone can claim, "My father is a great person," but he cannot pass off as a great man just because he is a son of a great man. No. Simply because his father is very highly qualified, doesn't mean he necessarily would have acquired all the father's qualifications, unless he is trained. Training is required, education is required, culture is required. All that is required. It doesn't simply come off. Automatically there is no such transfer of qualities.
